segments.text: beg, borrow, or steal. That's how some
fortunes are made. And these three
German brothers turned it into their
billion-dollar formula. In 1998, they
noticed the rise of a new platform
called eBay and thought, "If it worked
in the US, why not in Germany?" So, the
brothers went home with a new plan to
build their own eBay called Orlando,
proving the core idea of the millionaire
fast lane, that you don't get rich
working for a system, you get rich
building and owning a system. And in
just 100 days, their platform exploded,
gaining thousands of users and listings.
It worked so well that eBay bought it
for a jaw-dropping $43 million. That win
became their blueprint to turn the next
big idea into millions fast. Then they
launched Rocket Internet, a venture
studio dedicated to the art of cloning.
And their formula was simple. Duplicate
successful US businesses with a proven
need. Launch them in foreign countries
with low barriers to entry. and then
sell them to the original company. Over
the next few years, they cloned
companies like these, scaled them to
market dominance, and sold each for
hundreds of millions, making them
billionaires from pure borrowed
brilliance.

fullText: beg, borrow, or steal. That's how some fortunes are made. And these three German brothers turned it into their billion-dollar formula. In 1998, they noticed the rise of a new platform called eBay and thought, "If it worked in the US, why not in Germany?" So, the brothers went home with a new plan to build their own eBay called Orlando, proving the core idea of the millionaire fast lane, that you don't get rich working for a system, you get rich building and owning a system. And in just 100 days, their platform exploded, gaining thousands of users and listings. It worked so well that eBay bought it for a jaw-dropping $43 million. That win became their blueprint to turn the next big idea into millions fast. Then they launched Rocket Internet, a venture studio dedicated to the art of cloning. And their formula was simple. Duplicate successful US businesses with a proven need. Launch them in foreign countries with low barriers to entry. and then sell them to the original company. Over the next few years, they cloned companies like these, scaled them to market dominance, and sold each for hundreds of millions, making them billionaires from pure borrowed brilliance.
